Today is the 62nd anniversary of #ToKillAMockingbird ‚ú®Today we celebrate American author Harper Lee who won a Pulitzer Prize for To Kill A Mockingbird, which is about gentle Southern lawyer Atticus Finch who incurs the wrath of his fellow townsfolk when he defends a black man accused of raping a white woman. 
.

This beloved novel found success in part because it poses the fundamental question of ‚Äúhow do I get along with people who are different from me?" In Mockingbird, Scout and Jem learn to empathise with Tom Robinson, the accused black man, and to understand the misunderstood recluse Boo Bradley. They learn to view the residents of their town with compassion and understanding, rather than bitterness and anger.
.
.
Mockingbird explores themes of racial prejudice and injustice as well as love and the coming-of-age of Scout and Jem, Finch's children. It was published just as the United States civil rights movement was gaining momentum and has resonated with readers across cultural lines.
.

Overview: 
The unforgettable novel of a childhood in a sleepy Southern town and the crisis of conscience that rocked it. "To Kill A Mockingbird" became both an instant bestseller and a critical success when it was first published in 1960. It went on to win the Pulitzer Prize in 1961 and was later made into an Academy Award-winning film, also a classic.

Compassionate, dramatic, and deeply moving, "To Kill A Mockingbird" takes readers to the roots of human behavior - to innocence and experience, kindness and cruelty, love and hatred, humor and pathos. Now with over 18 million copies in print and translated into forty languages, this regional story by a young Alabama woman claims universal appeal. Harper Lee always considered her book to be a simple love story. Today it is regarded as a masterpiece of American literature.

It's banned books week, and one of the most banned books is To Kill a Mockingbird. Even though this book is a beloved classic conveying the racism of the time, even some versions of the book take out the n-word in order to not offend people, a different kind of censorship. I personally don't believe that any book (even ones offensive to me) should be banned (though they might need a warning label for younger readers). 
What is your opinion about censorship/banned books?

Ok so don‚Äôt fight me because I know how you girls like to tussle‚Ä¶ but I found this ok. I think other people really built it up for me so when I finished the book, I was literally sat there like ‚Äú‚Ä¶ok??‚Äù

I can definitely see how this would have a huge impact on someone. Especially if this were to be read during those formative years. I can also certainly appreciate it in respect of when it was written and the subject it focuses on. 

It was very well written and Scout is likeable and seeing the world through her eyes was nice. I also absolutely adored Arthur Radley, he seemed like a sweet soul. 

If this had been written now, it would be a bit too ‚Äúwhite saviour‚Äù for me but again, thinking about the time period it was written in, I can completely understand how this was (and still is) so thought provoking. 

I had mixed feelings about Atticus himself as a parent but that‚Äôs neither here nor there. I felt like it took forever to get to the trial and I wished it had lasted longer. That was probably my favourite part of the book and it didn‚Äôt last long at all, I wanted more suspense. What happened to Tom in the end was also really sad, I guess it was realistic but I wish his story didn‚Äôt end the way in which it did. 

I am glad I read it though and will be reading the sequel soon, hopefully.

 The Winner of Pulitzer prize, this classic novel is mainly based on racism towards black people. The setting of the story is a small town in Albama district of United States during the era of great depression. The story firstly evolves around scout finch, a six years old girl, her brother jem, neighbour friend dill, her father Atticus finch and their surrounding neighbourhood.

Through the sharp and smart  character of scout finch, the author has raised many serious questions and pointed finger to the unjustly prejudices prevalent on those days regarding racism, poverty and social inequality. The simple story of childhood adventure takes a twisty turn when atticus finch who was a lawyer by profession stood upto defend Tom Robinson, a black man who was accused of raping a white woman. The author very tactfully showed how the black community was targeted often and falsely accused of the crime they didn't committed. How that community even denied of their basic rights. Apart from the black community the author also disclosed the inequality and oppression of women in the society alongside  the hollowness of other social prejudices. 
Lastly, this novel also carefully delivers the message of good parenting as Atticus finch teaches his children about ethics, equality and standing up for right even if alone.

My take on the novel is that what Harper Lee did want to covey that time, is even apt till the present day. Because somewhere in this world still there are people or communities that facing some kind of inequality regarding cast, creed, religion or gender.This novel advocate for those deprived communities. It encourages us to go against the flow to defend truth and justice, as the world very much needs it and thus makes it a must read book for all of us.
